page.title: 11GEOLOGY
page.content: The Mendip Hills are virtually made entirely of limestone. Limestone is made up of mainly calcite but all limestones contain a small proportion of quartz, clay and other minerals. The calcite probably derived from coral or algae millions of years ago but possibly also from sea shells. Layers of flint nodules and pyrite crystals can be found in all limestone. The colour of the stone varies from white to yellow or green to red if the limestone contains iron. Grey and black limestone occurs from time to time if the rock contains a large amount of plant material. Fossils are frequently found in the limestone on the Mendips. Ammonite fossils are often found but fossils of other brachiopods such as cockles and mussels are also common.
